awd_titl_txt: A Community College and Industry Partnership to Produce a Highly Qualified Cybersecurity Workforce
awd_abstract_narration:
Keeping computers and information systems secure is a major challenge. Business, industry, and government need well-prepared technicians who can prevent, detect, and investigate cybersecurity breaches.  The growth of cyber-threats has created a need for many more workers who have appropriate, specific knowledge and skills. Nationwide, employer surveys indicate that only a small percentage of universities and colleges fully prepare graduates for cybersecurity jobs.  Colorado is a major hub for cybersecurity jobs, with over 9,000 open cybersecurity positions in the Denver Metro and Colorado Springs areas, which are served by the college. Over 1,200 of these jobs can be filled by individuals who have an Associate of Applied Science (AAS) degree. This project will prepare well-qualified cybersecurity professionals and information security analysts to benefit the regional workforce. The project will create and implement a responsive AAS cybersecurity program aligned with business needs and Federal standards. The approach will focus on integrating experiential and project-based learning to provide students with real-world experiences, to create seamless continuity from classroom to workforce, and to equip students with 21st-century employability skills. The college intends to achieve a Center of Academic Excellence in Cyber Defense designation. This designation, along with mapping the curriculum to the Federal standards, will equip students with the necessary knowledge, skills, and abilities to protect and defend the nation's infrastructure. The project will also focus on increasing the participation of women in cybersecurity. 

The project has three goals: (1) to address the unmet demand for cybersecurity technicians in the region served by the college; (2) to enhance gender diversity in cybersecurity by recruiting more female students into the program (the aim is for at least 20% of the students to be women); and (3) to improve retention and persistence in the attainment of an AAS degree in cybersecurity. The project will adopt, adapt, and evaluate materials and methods developed through the Colorado Community College System, the National CyberWatch Center, and other NSF Advanced Technological Education projects.  It will also develop a new course in Security Risk Management. Collaboration with a regional Business and Industry Leadership Team will ensure that the project can create a robust curriculum that provides seamless continuity from the classroom to the workplace and meets industry standards. In addition, collaboration with a subject matter expert on diversity and organizational change, along with partnerships with high schools, will facilitate the recruitment, retention, and completion of women in the college's cybersecurity program. By using distance education and remote-access labs, the project will reach beyond Colorado. The new courses that are developed will be added to the CCCS database and will be available for all 13 colleges in the system and other colleges across the nation. The best practices that are discovered will be disseminated nationally through the National CyberWatch Center, ATE Central, the Community College Cyber Summit, and the National Convergence Technology Center, as well as through national conferences that focus on cybersecurity and experiential education.  This project is funded by the Advanced Technological Education program, which focuses on the education of technicians for the advanced-technology fields that drive the nation's economy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: STATE BOARD FOR COMMUNITY COLLEGES & OCCUPATIONAL EDUCATION ARAPAHOE COMMUNITY COLLEGE

por.por_cntn:
Through this project Arapahoe Communicty College addressed the nationwide challenge in education and the critical workforce shortage ofqualified cybersecurity professionals and information security analysts by creating a responsive cybersecurity program aligned with business needs and federal standards. Our innovative approach focuses on integrating experiential and project-based learning to provide students with real-worldexperiences, create seamless continuity from classroom to workforce, and equip them with 21st century employability skills. The project will adopted, adapted, and evaluated materials and methods developed through the Colorado Community College System (CCCS), ATE National Center in Cybersecurity, CyberWatch, and other ATE projects. Mapping the curriculum to the Center of Academic Excellence in Cyber Defense (CAE-CD) standards will equip students with the necessary knowledge, skills, and abilities to protect and defend our nation’s infrastructures. Arapahoe Cyber also addressed the underrepresentation of women in our cybersecurity courses and in the cybersecurity profession. Over the course of the grant, at least 20% of our projected students will be females.

Objective 1.1: Develop a responsive and rigorous cybersecurity program aligned with business needs and federal standards to fulfill unmet workforce demands for qualified cybersecurity technicians.

Objective 1.2: Enhance the cybersecurity curriculum with 21st century employability skills.

Objective 1.3: Align the cybersecurity curriculum with federal standards.

Objective 1.4: Ensure the sustainability of the program by increasing the qualified faculty members at the college who can teach the cybersecurity curriculum.

Objective 2.1: Build an education pipeline model with high schools to encourage students (especially females) at an early age to enter the cybersecurity fields of study through the degree program at ACC.

Objective 2.2: Increase and sustain the gender diversity in the cybersecurity program by recruiting more female students in the program and improve retention and persistence in the attainment of an Associate of Applied Science (AAS) degree in Cybersecurity.

Intellectual Merit

This project addressed an unmet demand for cybersecurity technicians in Arapahoe Community College's (ACC) service area.  A Cybersecurity academic program was developed by ACC to include sixteen 1000/2000 level courses and eleven 3000/4000 level courses. A 2-year Associate of Applied Science, 4-year Bachelor of Applied Science and a 2+2 articulation agreement with Colorado State University of Pueblo were designed to provide multiple options for students to complete a degree path leading to a degree in Cybersecurity.

Broader Impacts

  • Developed and/or revised sixteen 1000 & 2000 level courses to include Cybersecurity curriculum.
  • Developed eleven new 3000 & 4000 Cybersecurity courses as part of a Statewide consortium of community colleges.
  • Launched a 2-year AAS in Cybersecurity.
  • Launched a 4-year BAS in Cybersecurity.
  • Developed a 2+2 articulation agreement between the ACC Sturm Collaboration Campus and Colorado State University Pueblo to allow seamless matriculation of students from ACC to CSU Pueblo's Cybersecurity program. 
  • Number of students completing a Cybersecurity class during the term of this project = 5,263. (This is a duplicated count.)
  • Number of students completing a Cybersecurity degree from ACC during the term of this project = 68. 

 

 


Last Modified: 10/29/2024
Modified by: Calhoun D Calhoun
